title: What is the difference between a steam engine & a steam turbine? - Quora

response.answer_text: A steam engine is a general term for a heat engine which relies on externally produced hot steam that expands under pressure to do work. The expansion is used to move mechanical parts, resulting in the rotary motion of a shaft which can then be put to various uses. A steam engine can be either reciprocating or a turbine: Reciprocating means the hot steam moves a piston up and down, which is connected to a crank-shaft to produce the rotary motion. There are different arrangements of pistons, depending on the type of engine and application. Historical marine engines had up to six pistons.Turbine means that instead of pistons, the steam pushes against the blades of a "fan", causing direct rotary motion. This “fan” is quite complex and has many sets of blades.At high speeds the turbine is more efficient than the reciprocating engine. It is also easier to maintain than a reciprocating engine. For these reasons the turbine is the only type of steam engine in use today.

Steam 	engines and steam turbines are steam expanders but differ in 	mechanical construction, working principle, capacitiesSteam 	engines started the first industrial revolution. Steam engines are 	positive displacement reciprocating expander wherein the steam 	expansion takes place with the movement of piston inside a cylinder. 	Piston is connected to a crankshaft through linkages (slider & 	bar mechanism). Steam power is transferred to crankshaft from piston 	through these linkages. Mechanical power is available at the 	crankshaft. Initially steam engines were employed for mechanical 	work like water pumping, crushing of sugarcane, rice / dal 	processing mills, etc. Initial days all the locomotive were powered 	by steam engines. Even today there are few engines powering toy 	trains in India. All these engines were very big in size since they 	were operating all very low speeds up to 100 rpm and their 	capacities were in kW range resulting in low efficiencies. With 	increase in demand, steam engines with low power density and too 	many moving components were found to be not capable of scaling up to 	MW rangeSteam 	turbines are rotary expander devices addressing these demand of MW 	level electricity generation with very high speeds (3000 to 30000 	rpm) and high efficiency resulting in high power density and lower 	costs. Steam expansion takes place either in stationary blades 	called nozzles if it’s single stage impulse turbine or in both 	nozzles and moving blades in reaction turbines. Nozzles reduces the 	pressure (i.e. enthalpy) and convert it in to velocity. High 	velocity steam like a jet impacts on the blades mounted on a rotor 	which starts rotating due to this. Rotor is mounted on a shaft which 	is connected to the electrical generator to convert the mechanical 	power in to electricity. There are many configurations and types of 	steam turbines used. In Rankine cycle thermal power plants 	multi-stage condensing steam turbines (50 MWe and more) are used. In 	process industries for CHP application (in place of PRV) mostly 	single stage impulse back pressure steam turbines are employed which 	are in the range of 10 kWe to 1 MWe capacities.
